body:
By the way, the API REFERENCE of document is lost.
[http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/packages/python/symbol.html#execution-api-reference](http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/en/latest/packages/python/symbol.html#execution-api-reference)

@wellner @Ldpe2G I see. Not in the roadmap for this coming version.
@Ldpe2G I sent you an email, could you check your mailbox once you have time?

@zihaolucky Yes, just add maven deps to the pom. While the current versions in maven repositories are somewhat out-of-date. We'll release the 1.0 version in the next few months.

The .so is packed into the jar. Check https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/scala-package#install for more infos.
Yes, CustomOp was what I meant. I couldn't argue to prioritize it higher than what you've outlined, but wanted to check!
@javelinjs ok
close as duplicate

depends on the cmdline arguments you use.
im2rec.py's usage explains it

@piiswrong 

Thank you for your reply. Dump to some variable. Actually what I want to do is to have the gradient of intermediate layer output (also the intermediate layer output), just like the data gradient as saliency map. Since the executor can have the grad of arg, therefore I want to take advantage of this feature.

@piiswrong I have no experiments on compiler and code generation.But I would like to learn to use Halide and LLVM for doing this.
Will NNVM rewrite the implementation of operators from C++ to Halide?
Do you plan to support high order functions in operators by code generation?
Such that we can use imperative operations such as `if for` to define a symbol variable and compile it to execute efficiently.
And by code generation,the optimization similarly to above can be done by associating some successive operators into one operator then we can do a lot of optimizations in it.
@wellner We'll support it once the TODOs here are finished. Do you heavily rely on this feature?

both http://mxnet.io/ and https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/docs/

On Tue, Aug 23, 2016 at 3:23 AM, Jon notifications@github.com wrote:

> Which site has the up-to-date and correct version of doc/api?
> http://mxnet.io/
> http://mxnet.readthedocs.io/
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/tree/master/docs/
> http://newdocs.readthedocs.io/
> 
> â€”
> You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/3080#issuecomment-241689712, or mute
> the thread
> https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAZv4bPnDBPG0JxVHzA3PATm3xiejj1zks5qisorgaJpZM4Jo-pq
> .
@javelinjs  Thanks for asking. No, definitely not heavily but some future/potential plans might rely on it, see #3118

there are instructions for how to build opencv without gpu:

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/docs/how_to/build.md#build-opencv-from-source

related issue https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/3012
in python you can stack a `PrefetchingIter` to do prefetch. other iterators implemented in c++ such as recordioiter do prefetch in default

it depends how `cv2.imread` handles such situations, see

https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/tools/im2rec.py#L77
@yzhang87 @pluskid
it may be your network is small, it already runs quite fast. there is extra communication cost for using two gpus. it's only worth if your network is large.

ping if the problem is solved. note that `-i 0` only set for gpu 0. you'd better remove `-i 0` to make it apply to all gpus.

a related blog: https://devblogs.nvidia.com/parallelforall/increase-performance-gpu-boost-k80-autoboost/

if i understand the output at the end of your notebook, it process about 6k examples per second. according to the answer at the end of https://github.com/zhangxiangxiao/Crepe/issues/20, each epoch has around 500k examples. so it should only 1.5min to process an epoch. 

btw, i think xiangxiao uses different items than us: 

xiangxiao,  mxnet
eras => epoch
epoch => batch
`device` will do the merge and weight update on gpu, may result in worse numerical accuracy, but should be ok. can you check it again? we reverted a charge to `device` some days ago
use negative learning rate for some layers?
You can group the intermediate layer output with the final output. You can also bind the gradient of intermediate layer's output
NNVM itself doesn't include rewrite a operators, but it makes it easier for you to add a parallel track of Halide operators that can be optionally turned on.
3D convolution seems merged. 3D deconvolution would be another big plus.

- what I mean is use symbol.load_json to load them in, 
- use symbol.get_internals to get the internal parts
- recompose the later parts that you need to change
Perfect thank you. That was what I was looking for.
@mli Thank you for your reply, I got it.
please refer to opencv's document

As a first step, I add both NNPACK and MKL DNN in forward convolution function. I have tested the prediction accuracy, it's the same with original implement. 

As NNPACK can't support stride when batch size is large than 1, I compare the performance on VGG-19 model. The forward performance(Batch size 128) on Intel(R) Xeon(R) CPU E5-2699 v4 @ 2.20GHz is shown as below:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14191863/17921485/aa6ede2c-6a0c-11e6-8d21-a9dc9c489705.png)

The MKL DNN implement can achieve 2.6x performance, and has no problem on core number scalability. 
The NNPACK implement can achieve 50% higher performance than MKL DNN implement on single core, but the core number scalability is really poor. @Maratyszcza Do you have a plan to fix the scalability issue?
sorry everyone, it's my fault. I did not pass the `aux_params` to the `executor` correctly. Now the difference between cpu mode and gpu mode is about `10e-8`, I think it is reasonable.

@LeagueOfCodes   Hi, I have a problem when install mxnet on Tegra X1 : gcc can't  recognize option '-mess3', i try  commented 'mess3' out. but it have other mistake like miss '*.h' file. Could you help me
@piiswrong thanks a lot! You were right. X-forwarding has solved the problem.

Thank you @mli, I see what you're saying:

My batch-size is 128; and it does 50 batches (6400 samples) in around 105 seconds. Which is the same speed for my whole epoch of 2,100,000 reviews \* (105/6500) = 565 minutes. So to do 10 epochs will cost me 4 days ... which is similar to the reported run-time of the model.

The per second rate is 6400/105 which is 60 so I'm not sure why the speedometer is giving that speed in the log?

What's a bit worrying is that I am on the 2nd epoch (lets say out of 10) and my accuracy on training is 0.51 ... I don't think it's realistic to assume it will hit 0.95 by epoch 10:

```
2016-08-24 10:19:14,630 - root - INFO - Epoch[2] Batch [5800]   Speed: 6059.23 samples/sec  Train-accuracy=0.500156
2016-08-24 10:21:01,582 - root - INFO - Epoch[2] Batch [5850]   Speed: 5984.89 samples/sec  Train-accuracy=0.512344
2016-08-24 10:22:46,565 - root - INFO - Epoch[2] Batch [5900]   Speed: 6096.17 samples/sec  Train-accuracy=0.511563
```

Hi @albertyou2 I also met this problem and I agree with you. 
I updated my mxnet to the latest so far, and I ran a cifar10 example with record data downloaded from http://data.dmlc.ml/mxnet/data/cifar10.zip, the training accuracy looks like normal but validation accuracy is bad (barely increase after an epoch). 
Then, I replace ImageRecordIter for validation set with an ImageDataIter that directly read image from the disk, and this time the validation accuracy is good. 
I trained an Inception-BN model that defines in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/image-classification/symbol_inception-bn-28-small.py by using two GPUs with cudnn_v5.1 on a single machine.
Hope this may help you find the problem as soon as possible.
Ah, I think I can see how to do that via a combination of shared weights and explicitly setting learning rates (negative).  Thanks!!
Comments addressed
i have the same problem

@zhangjiulong seems like you need to change label size.

btw, you can change these parameters by passing "--train-xdim" into the python file.

great idea on group intermediate layer output with the final output! (I guess BlockGrad symbol is also needed here.) But I don't understand what do you mean by bind the gradient? It would be very helpful for me if you could provide a simple code example. Thank you.

```
model = mx.model.FeedForward(
    symbol = mlp,
    num_epoch = 20,
    learning_rate = .1)
model.fit(X = train, eval_data = val)
```

You should transfer the computation graph(symbol) to model.feedforward
Would be awesome if we also have pre-trained models available.

Turns out I have misspecified the model and forgot to add a stride of 3 to the max-pooling which created much higher dimensions than necessary. Everything works fine now and I have posted the diagram [here](https://github.com/ilkarman/Bangalore_Sentiment/blob/master/mxnet/README.md).
nice document
@piiswrong @mli OK i see.

You can inherit mx.io.DataIter and read data from lmdb.
I don't recommend it though. lmdb seems to have random slowdown problems when data is bigger than memory.
provide data/label describes the data name and shape

the accuracy vs iteration curve of the training. we can find a  clear drop at the start of every epoch.
![loss_curve](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3807357/17954232/0e4dcdfa-6aac-11e6-8e64-bfa92f23fb66.jpg)
git pull && git submodule update && cp make/osx.mk . && make clean && make

But I pulled code from origin/master just now , I didn't see the inception v4 code .
where did you put it?
@piiswrong Thanks.
when i download the up-to-date code and rebuild it again, the issue is gone!

@Johnqczhang Thank you very much ! Could you please show me how to use ImageDataIter? 
I want to try this solution.
@albertyou2 example/image-classification, but these files have not been merged yet.
@Trangle ok i see.

@albertyou2 The function of this DataIter is similar with ImageData layer in caffe. To use this DataIter, you should specify the image list file (.lst file) and the root directory of images, and specify other params just like ImageRecordIter. You can see an example here: https://github.com/Johnqczhang/mxnet/blob/mymxnet/example/image-classification/train_cifar10_img.py#L102, and the source code of ImageDataIter is in https://github.com/Johnqczhang/mxnet/blob/mymxnet/python/mxnet/io.py#L699.
If you find any bug or problem, please let me know. Thanks!
@Johnqczhang Thanks! I 'll try your data tier. It will take me a few  days because  I don't familiar  with caffe and python. I will let you know the result ! Thank you again !
Looks like baidu ctc's problem. See if you can run their test successfully
as I said, running test_gpu is failed.

Does it seems like this?

path/to/image 0
path/to/image 0
...
path/to/image 1
path/to/image 1
..
path/to/image 2
path/to/image 2

Could I put all  the images into one list file?I saw that you split image into 10 lst files

HI  @Johnqczhang : 
you mean i can use imageDataIter  like this? 

train = mx.io.ImageDataIter(
        img_lst     = args.data_dir + "/train_lm_all_2.lst", # created by im2rec.py 
        mean_rgb    = (117,117,117),
        data_shape  = data_shape,
        batch_size  = args.batch_size,
        root        = args.data_dir + '/train_lm/')  # a path include training and validation images 

```
val = mx.io.ImageDataIter(
    img_lst     = args.data_dir + "/val_lm_all_2.lst",
    mean_rgb    = (117,117,117),
    data_shape  = data_shape,
    batch_size  = args.batch_size,
    root        = args.data_dir + '/train_lm/')
```

How to resize images?
Should imagedataiter resize images automatic if the given data_shape is different from the image size ? Or should I resize them first?

@albertyou2 The data_shape is 3-dim tuple, e.g., (3, 224, 224) that will be input into the data layer of the network. If the given data_shape is smaller than your image, the ImageDataIter will automatically crop a patch which size is equal to data_shape; if larger, then you should give an integer to param 'resize_dims' to specify the resize size that the shorter side of your image will be resized. 
You can see the details of image preprocessing in here: https://github.com/Johnqczhang/mxnet/blob/mymxnet/python/mxnet/io.py#L611

I have changed the plugin/warpctc to support only cpu side ctc even though the ctxdev is gpu. Do you need it?

@Johnqczhang HI:)
why the reading image process so slow? My training data size is 138385.
I laughed my training program  40 minutes ago,and now it is still reading image.

This is a python signal handling problem. You need to register a signal handler that kill all processes on ctrl-c.
I forgot how to do it exactly but should be easy to google
@albertyou2 Did you save the log file to check the process? From my test, it's speed is similar with reading from record data.
This code runs well at my version. Please update your mxnet to the newest version.

Thank you, you are right. But I want to get the more general operation like this: 
A=mx.symbol.Variable('A')
B=[1,2,3,4]
C=A+B

B is a matrix or a vector. Does mxnet has the element-wise operation of symbol and constant matrix?

The NaN problem is solved by updating to the newest version of mxnet. It turns out to be a bug of the pooling layer, the behaviour was very strange: the output value of previous layer (relu) are very small, but after one max pooling, the values become extremely large.

Now I get the same result with my early matconvnet work, but still with different initial learning rate (1e-4 v.s. 1e-6). The possible explanation could be the normalization of softmax output (the size of output score map is 34 \* 34 \* n). But I set the  normalization to be "null". Isn't that means no normalization at the softmax calculation?
Please use B=mx.nd.array([1,2,3,4])

The problem of your code i think is that the name of your data is different from the variable name of your network.  The default name of label data is `softmax`. So you should set the name of LogisticOutput layer `softmax` instead of `label`.

'''
label = mx.sym.Variable("label")
logicr= mx.symbol.LogisticRegressionOutput(data=fc1, label=label, name='logicr')  
return logicr
model = mx.mod.Module(symbol=logicr, data_names=('data',), label_names=('label',))
model.bind(data_shapes=train_dataiter.provide_data, label_shapes=train_dataiter.provide_label)
'''
in above code, which should be replaced by 'softmax' ?
thanks.
In addition,the two model worked well in forward operation.
@tqchen
still the same error.
ready to merge this in?
@piiswrong is this ready to get merged?

@recastrodiaz I'd be very interested in trying out the ccrmsprop if you can get it merged.  MXNet is one of the few deep learning frameworks that is reasonable in C++, and having more choices for optimizers would be a great step forward.

We tried warming up with 0.01 learning rate like in the paper, and even 0.005 learning rate. There appears to be a large discrepancy between R and Python implementations. Python implementation works very well, but in R there appears to be something wrong with how the error on the validation set is computed - please see the attached plot. Even with 0.005 learning rate, it makes no sense for R implementation to have better accuracy on the validation set than on the training set in the first 60 epochs with the default settings. The validation set accuracy is also extremely volatile.
![accuracy](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/19535372/17980070/abfcbe02-6acb-11e6-9c44-a8aae050e8f7.PNG)
Addressed comments except the ProdShape() ones that I didn't understand
I will add caffe plugin CMakeLists.txt changes in a separate review after this review

Believe it or not I'm back and finally I have a proper env with CUDA.
Just to be sure, right now it's about rewriting the SVMOutpt-inl.h this time using MakeLoss and Relu, right?
Does that solves the problem for cpu and gpu? If so, I'll test both for both cases just to be sure.
try `git submodule update` or use cudnn 5.1
Looks like we will need to adjust the input data - there seems to be a mismatch between how the data is fed into Python and R.
